tr.td: Mostly unknown to the medical profession
Frequent absence of specific IgG antibodies
Determined mainly by size or density of population and factors related to type of transmission, for example vector population
Type and speed of human transmission
Social interaction of populations, widespread common source
Ability of microbes to produce disease (minimal infective dose)
Proportion of completely asymptomatic cases, super-spreaders, and evident and pathognomonic disease markers
Need for hospitalization, artificial ventilation, or intensive rehydration; chronicity or death

fn.p: Examples of interacting human factors include background immunity, means of transmission, and healthcare system quality.
